titleStmt.title: Co-designing get-out-the-vote messaging with youth increases message effectiveness

div.p: Voting is a critical component of representative democracy but yields consistently low engagement from young Americans. Online communication interventions have the potential to catalyze action, but evidence regarding best practices for digital, youth-focused get-out-the-vote (GOTV) messaging is sparse. Guided by the Theory of Planned Behavior and Reasoned Action approaches, we integrated formative and participatory research approaches to fill this gap. In a partnership between communication researchers and a college student-led GOTV organization, we conducted formative research integrating experiential knowledge from youth partners with scientific evidence to generate a set of voting beliefs. We used the standard Hornik & Woolf method to select promising beliefs to target in messaging but also conducted post-hoc analyses demonstrating the potential of network approaches that take into account relationships among beliefs to identify influential beliefs. We then co-designed belief-informed GOTV messages that could be disseminated via social media and tested message effects in both local and national samples of college students. We found that the messages co-designed with youth to target promising voting beliefs were more motivating, persuasive, and self-relevant than existing GOTV social media messages from a national youth-focused campaign. They were also more motivating and persuasive than prior messages from our student-led GOTV partner organization-which were not designed using formative research-suggesting that the combination of formative and participatory research practices increases message effectiveness. Overall, these studies highlight the importance of engaging youth in voting research and illustrate the benefits of integrating theory-based formative research, network approaches, and human-centered participatory practices to develop messaging campaigns.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In the U.S. and other representative democracies, voting is a crucial mechanism that enables citizens to express opinions and influence political outcomes. However, approximately one in five eligible voters in the United States is not registered to vote (Pew, 2022). Out of all age groups, youth and young adults aged 18-29 also tend to have the lowest turnout (Pew, 2023a). Despite lower voting turnout, they are not apathetic (CIRCLE, 2025a). Youth express high levels of concern about political issues (Pew, 2018;Martin, 2012;Pew, 2023b), have a degree of interest in political issues comparable to older generations (Holbein and Hillygus 2020;Bergan et al., 2021), and engage in other political behaviors such as boycotting/buycotting, signing petitions, or attending protests and demonstrations (Zukin et al., 2006;CIRCLE, 2023a). This highlights the potential to leverage communication interventions to convert political interest into motivation to vote. Indeed, numerous nonprofit organizations, such as Rock the Vote and NextGen America , are focused solely on registering and turning out youth to vote. Given their digital nativity (Teo, 2013), messaging strategies can reach youth through social media and other online resources (Delli Carpini, 2000). However, scientific evidence is sparse regarding what communication interventions are most effective for youth, particularly on social media. We address this gap using a fully collaborative, participatory action research approach in partnership with youth to design theory-based, youth-focused GOTV messages that can be disseminated on social media.

div.head: Youth voting
div.p: Youth and young adults aged 18-29 consistently have lower voting turnout than older adults (Pew, 2023a;Bergan et al., 2021). A commonly cited barrier for youth is a sense of having insufficient knowledge or information about the registration and voting process or candidates and issues (Knoester & Kretz, 2017;Knoester & Gichiru, 2021;Kawashima-Ginsburg and Kiesa, 2019;Bergan et al., 2021;CIRCLE, 2023a). However, psychological and social factors such as self-efficacy, political efficacy, civic duty, social norms, or affiliation with a social movement also affect motivation to vote in youth (Knoester & Kretz, 2017;Kawashima-Ginsburg & Kiesa, 2019;CIRCLE, 2022;Apau et al., 2025;Levy & Akiva, 2019;Condon & Holleque, 2013;Glynn et al., 2009;Bergan et al., 2021;Lydic et al., 2025).

Prior research has explored a variety of strategies to increase youth voting, including informational and civic education interventions (Feldman et al., 2007;McDevitt & Chaffee, 2000;Syvertsen et al., 2009;Bergan et al., 2021;Bennion and Nickerson, 2016;Haenschen & and Jennings, 2019), events that aim to foster political socialization (Howard & Posler, 2012;Bennion & Michelson, 2023), and voting pledge campaigns (Costa et al. 2018;Bergan et al., 2021;Burgess et al., 2000). Many of these interventions have been implemented on college campuses, where there is a unique proximity to youth and resources to organize GOTV activities (Bennion & Michelson, 2023). However, these campus-based campaigns can be difficult to scale, and there has been relatively less research on mass communication interventions to increase youth turnout.

GOTV communication research has demonstrated that media efforts can support youth voting, but the effects are often small and findings are inconsistent across studies. Impersonal, mass media messages have particularly inconsistent effects. For example, Rock the Vote television ads, which target young voters, have been considered both effective and cost-competitive methods for increasing youth turnout (Green & Vavreck, 2006). On the other hand, Rock the Vote spent more money on these ads with less impact than other campaigns at the time, and did not address the most frequent barriers reported by youth (Richards, 2012;Orr & Hoover, 2007). Prior work has also shown mixed results about the role of subtle linguistic cues in GOTV messaging. For example, in majority young-adult samples, - Bryan et al. (2011) found that "invoking the self" by framing voting questions around a sense of identity ("being a voter") was more effective than framing questions around the behavior itself ("voting"), though this intervention was less effective in other studies including older adults (Gerber et al., 2016).

Beyond mixed evidence regarding which message frames are most effective, Nickerson (2006) found that GOTV efforts can be as effective for youth (18-24) as older adults, but that youth are harder to contact via phone or door-to-door canvassing. Indeed, youth are contacted less frequently than older adults before elections (CIRCLE, 2022). Thus, strategies that adopt youths' preferred communication systems could yield greater reach, highlighting the necessity for more research on messaging campaign design, delivery, and impact in online spaces. Employing social media as a dissemination tool for GOTV messaging campaigns, Teresi & Michelson (2015) found that GOTV messages delivered through online social networks can increase turnout in college students. However, Unan et al. (2024) found null effects of social media messaging campaigns on young voter (aged 18-35) registration across three studies in the U.K. Prior work has thus yielded inconclusive evidence for best practices in GOTV social media communication efforts. Additionally, researchers and practitioners alike could better engage youth in the development of messaging campaigns. Prior qualitative evaluation of youth-led GOTV efforts highlights their potential for success (Jameson-Charles & Charles, 2022), but quantitative evidence is lacking.

div.head: GOTV campaign development
div.p: Borrowing from theories of health messaging campaign development (Fishbein & Ajzen, 2010), we argue that GOTV communication strategies may be more effective if campaigns address the beliefs about voting that are most malleable and most likely to lead to action if successfully targeted by persuasive messaging. That is, real-world GOTV messaging can benefit from integrating theories of behavior change, such as the Theory of Planned Behavior, which centers behavioral, normative, and control beliefs as targets for behavior change (Fishbein & Ajzen, 2010;Ajzen, 1991;Ajzen & Fishbein, 1980;Fishbein & Ajzen, 1975).

div.head: Theory of Planned Behavior
div.p: The Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) proposes that intentions and behavior are shaped by upstream beliefs about the behavior (behavioral beliefs), how normative it is (normative beliefs), and one's ability to engage in the behavior (control beliefs). Prior research has identified numerous classes of beliefs that are associated with voting intentions and behavior. With respect to behavioral beliefs, individuals are more likely to vote if they view voting as their personal (Bali et al., 2020), civic (Lydic et al., 2025;Harder & Krosnick, 2008), or moral duty (Blais & Daoust, 2020); see voting as important to them personally (Knoester & Kretz, 2017); have high political interest (Levy & Akiva, 2019); expect the outcome of the election to benefit themselves (Bali et al., 2020); and anticipate experiencing positive or negative emotions as a result of the election (Knight & Peterson, 2022). Having high trust in government or faith in the political system (CIRCLE, 2023a;Kawashima-Ginsburg & Kiesa, 2019;Apau et al., 2025) and believing that it is responsive to the public (i.e., external political efficacy; Harder & Krosnick, 2008) are also positively associated with voting. Normative beliefs that voting can promote solidarity (Harder & Krosnick, 2008) and belonging (Bali et al., 2020), and is engaged in by in-group members (Glynn et al., 2009;Bergan et al., 2021) are also positively associated with voting. Control beliefs related to political efficacy and self-efficacy (Condon & Holleque, 2013;Harder & Krosnick, 2008), having civic knowledge and skills (Maiello et al., 2003), ease of registration and voting (Harder & Krosnick, 2008), and knowledge about candidates and ballot measures (Knoester & Kretz, 2017;Knoester & Gichiru, 2021;Kawashima-Ginsburg and Kiesa, 2019;Bergan et al., 2021;CIRCLE, 2022) are also associated with whether individuals vote. Although prior work has shown that many of these beliefs are relevant in youth voting (Knight & Peterson, 2022;Lydic et al., 2025;Kawashima-Ginsburg & Kiesa, 2019;Apau et al., 2025;Glynn et al., 2009;Bergan et al., 2021;Condon & Holleque, 2013;Knoester & Kretz, 2017;Knoester & Gichiru, 2021;CIRCLE, 2022;Levy & Akiva, 2019), there has not been a systematic examination of these beliefs among college students to determine which beliefs might be most effectively targeted in messaging campaigns. Prior work has applied TPB to voting intentions and behavior in young adults (Glasford, 2008), but this study did not examine specific beliefs about voting. Moreover, extant research on voting beliefs does consider the relative strengths of associations between beliefs and voting intentions and behavior.

To identify voting beliefs among youth that can be targeted in messaging campaigns with the greatest potential impact, preliminary (formative) research on a broad range of specific behavioral beliefs is needed. Formative research is a preliminary research procedure to gather insights from the target population in order to inform messaging campaign or intervention design and tailoring (Capella, 2006;Martinez et al., 2012;Pleasant et al., 2020). Formative research practices solicit voices from the target population to direct intervention design towards changing particular beliefs that show the strongest relationships with the target behavior. Conducting formative research increases the success of interventions (Pleasant et al., 2020) and provides opportunities for the target population to inform the problem definition and offer nuanced perspectives on what motivates (or demotivates) their behavior.

div.head: Identifying promising beliefs through formative research
div.p: There is robust evidence from public health campaign research that designing messages to target promising beliefs, identified through formative research, is an effective way to shift behavioral intentions (Hornik and Woolfe, 1999;Hornik et al., 2018;Fishbein and Cappella, 2006). Reasoned Action models of behavior change, such as TPB, posit that behavior stems from a network of beliefs that shape attitudes about the behavior, which in turn influence intentions and subsequent behavior (Fishbein and Ajzen, 2010;Ajzen, 1991;Ajzen & Fishbein, 1980;Fishbein & Ajzen, 1975). Promising beliefs are those that are strongly associated with intentions to engage in a target behavior-in this case, voting-and can distinguish between people who do and do not intend to engage in the behavior. Crucially, promising beliefs should not already be widely held by the target population so that interventions have room to move beliefs (i.e., avoiding ceiling effects). By targeting promising beliefs, messaging interventions can increase belief strength, which in turn can increase intentions and behavior (Hornik and Woolfe, 1999;Hornik et al., 2018;Fishbein and Cappella, 2006). Although this approach is widely used in the field of health communication (Pleasant et al., 2020;Hornik et al., 2018), it has not yet been adopted to design GOTV messages. Although promising beliefs have been shown to be more strongly predictive of future behavior change than other beliefs (Hornik et al., 2018), messages targeting less promising beliefs can still induce positive effects if they are correlated with more promising beliefs (Lee et al., 2016). Therefore, it is also important to consider the relationships among beliefs when designing campaigns.

Recent research in political psychology and communication has applied network approaches to study relationships among beliefs (Brant & Sleegers, 2021;Vlasceanu et al., 2024). Psychological network approaches to understanding belief systems conceptualize beliefs as nodes in a network and the relationships between beliefs as edges connecting nodes. By constructing belief networks in this way, graph theory methods can be applied to understand network properties, how they differ among individuals and groups (Brandt, 2022;Brandt & Sleegers;2021;Vlasceanu et al., 2024), and how messaging (Keating, 2024) and other interventions can shift attitudes and behavior by targeting beliefs to induce changes in the network (Brant & Sleegers, 2021;Turner-Zwinkels & Brant, 2022;Vlasceanu et al., 2023). Examining the interrelationships among beliefs using network methods also has the potential to help researchers to identify beliefs with relatively stronger influence on the network that would make them promising intervention targets. As such, measures of network centrality-which index the relative importance and influence of nodes within a network based on their location and connections-may represent a complementary approach to identifying promising beliefs in formative research.

div.head: Youth participatory action research
div.p: Whereas traditional methods of formative research typically have limited engagement with the target population, participatory action research engages communities in deeper ways. Youth participatory action research (YPAR) is a research framework that engages youth in the process of problem identification; research design, implementation, and interpretation; and taking action to address the identified problem (Ozer et al., 2024, Ozer & Piatt, 2018;Cornish et al., 2023). Beyond the aim of producing knowledge through research, a primary goal of YPAR is to empower youth to identify and interrogate issues they are affected by, and develop and enact solutions to address them (Ozer et al., 2024;Ozer & Piatt, 2018). A guiding principle of YPAR is that youth are experts on their own experiences and can contribute meaningfully to the research process, and researchers can support youth to develop civic and research skills in the process (Cornish et al., 2023, Ozer et al., 2024). As a co-design process, YPAR provides a deeper opportunity to uplift youth voices in communication intervention and campaign development, where youth can offer their own expertise about what motivates and hinders them.

Though YPAR has been implemented to address a broad array of youth-relevant issues (Anyon et al., 2018), it has only recently begun to be applied in communication research. Recent research in health communication has demonstrated that formative research, message design, and message testing can be carried out with and benefit from a YPAR approach (Kikut-Stein et al., 2024;Kikut-Stein et al., 2025). In the present studies, we expand the YPAR-communication framework laid out in Kikut-Stein et al. (2024, 2025) to the domain of voting research, across all stages of campaign design.

div.head: The current studies
div.p: Prior evidence underscores the need for effective, evidence-based messaging strategies to motivate youth voting. We address this gap using a participatory approach that involved youth in all stages of a research process to create youth-focused GOTV messages to motivate voting on our local college campus during the 2024 general election. The study team included members of a communication research lab as well as members of a student-led, nonpartisan GOTV organization on campus, Penn Leads the Vote (PLTV). Across three studies, we conducted formative research to map voting beliefs among youth (18-25 year olds) and identify promising beliefs (Study 1). In addition to using the standard Hornik & Woolf method (1999) to select promising beliefs, we also applied a novel network approach that considers relationships among beliefs to identify influential beliefs. We then co-designed GOTV messages targeting these promising beliefs (Study 2) and evaluated how effective the co-designed messages were compared to existing GOTV messages from local and national campaigns (Study 3). This work represents a novel integration of theory-driven formative research and participatory practices to design GOTV messages for youth, with youth.

div.head: Study 1: Formative research on voting beliefs
div.p: In this study, we conducted survey research to identify promising beliefs about voting among college students that could be targeted in social media messages in subsequent studies. Although we used the Hornik & Woolf method to select promising beliefs during the 2024 election season, we also conducted post-hoc network analyses to examine the relationships among beliefs and explore centrality as a complementary method for promising belief identification.

div.head: Participants
div.p: Participants were recruited through listservs of undergraduate majors ( n = 136) and through the Human Subjects Pool at the University of Pennsylvania ( n = 184) in late August and early September 2024. Inclusion criteria were as follows: current Penn students, aged 18+ years, fluent in English, and eligible to vote in the November 2024 U.S. general election. Given that youth were our target audience, participants who were older than 25 were ultimately excluded from analysis ( n = 46). This resulted in a total of 274 participants who were aged 18-25 ( M = 20.1, SD = 1.4). Participants self-reported the following gender identities: 23.4% men, 74.1% women, 0.4% genderqueer, 0.4% non-binary, 1.5% preferred not to say, and 0.4% preferred to self-describe. With respect to race and ethnicity, participants identified as the following: 46.4% White, 22.4% East Asian, 10.2% Black or African American, 5.8% South Asian, 7.8% Southeast Asian, 2.0% Middle Eastern or North African, 0.3% American Indian or Alaskan Native, 0.7% Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander, and 1.4% other racial/ethnic identity not listed. 8.3% of participants also identified as Hispanic or Latina/o/x. This study was approved by the University of Pennsylvania Institutional Review Board and participants gave informed consent. Participants were compensated for participation via a $5 Amazon gift card or course credit for completing a 15-minute survey.

div.head: Belief identification
div.p: We generated a set of initial beliefs by identifying factors that may motivate people to vote, values and beliefs related to voting, and barriers that may make it difficult to vote. During this generation phase, we drew from the existing literature on voting behavior reviewed above, prior studies conducted by our team members (Lydic et al., 2025;Cosme et al., 2023), our personal experiences, and youth team members' conversations with peers about voting. In total, we generated 37 beliefs that we expected may be positively or negatively related to voting intentions. Example beliefs and associated themes are listed in Table 1 and all beliefs are listed in Table S1.

Table 1 Example beliefs tested in the formative research survey in Study 1 Theme Text Valence Self-efficacy It's too difficult or effortful to find out how to register to vote Negative Belonging Voting makes me feel like I'm part of a community Positive Self-relevance Voting is consistent with my core values Positive Instrumentality Voting can contribute to building a better world Positive Response efficacy Even if I vote, nothing will change for people like me Negative Personal impact

div.head: Procedure
div.p: Eligible participants completed an online survey administered via Qualtrics. After consenting, participants were presented with 37 belief statements (Table S1). For each statement, participants used a 7-point Likert-type scale to indicate their agreement, ranging from 1 = "Strongly Disagree" to 7 = "Strongly Agree," capturing participants' endorsement of each belief. Participants then completed a series of questionnaires designed to evaluate their attitudes, intentions, behaviors, and motivations regarding voting and civic engagement. Participants responded to 10 items based on the Theory of Planned Behavior (Ajzen, 1991) to assess intention to vote ("I plan to vote in the 2024 general election"; 1 = "Definitely not" to 7 = "Definitely yes") as well as intentions to register and make a plan, attitudes, norms, perceived behavioral control, and past voting behaviors. Correlations between beliefs and these additional measures are included in Supplementary Material (Table S4). Participants also completed additional measures of motivation, civic engagement, and civic attitudes that are not the focus of the present study. After completing these measures, participants responded to demographic questions and were provided with an opportunity to give feedback through an open-response question.

div.head: Promising beliefs
div.p: We used the Hornik & Woolf method (1999) to identify promising beliefs. We dichotomized the continuous measures of intentions to vote by categorizing people who selected "strongly agree" as "intenders" and people who selected any other option as "non-intenders." We followed a similar approach with the belief strength variables; beliefs for which participants selected "strongly (dis)agree" were recoded as "strong" beliefs, whereas beliefs for which any other values were selected were recoded as "weak" beliefs. Using these cross-tabs, we calculated the percentage to gain for each belief. Percentage to gain was calculated by subtracting the total percentage of people who intend to vote from the percentage of people who intend to vote and strongly endorse the belief. An example of this calculation is provided in Table 2 (97.8% -70.3% = 27.5% to gain). In addition to calculating the percentage to gain for each belief, we calculated the mean difference in continuous (i.e., non-dichotomized) belief strength for intenders and non-intenders, the correlation between continuous belief strength and intentions to vote, and the percentage to move , which reflects the number of people who do not strongly hold a belief. Higher values indicate greater potential for messaging campaigns to shift beliefs. 97.8%) a 192 (70.3%) b Total 181 (100.0%) 92 (100.0%) 273 (100.0%) Note . Percentage to gain is calculated per belief by subtracting the percentage of the sample that are intenders (denoted as b ) from the percentage of the sample that are intenders and hold a given belief strongly (denoted as a ).

div.head: Belief network
div.p: In post-hoc analyses, we explored the structure of the relationships among beliefs using a network approach. Specifically, we estimated a Gaussian Graphical Model-an undirected network of partial correlations-using the graphical LASSO (GLASSO) regularization algorithm (Friedman et al., 2008) to obtain a sparse network implemented in the qgraph package (Epskamp et al., 2012). We chose this method because simulation studies indicate that this method can recover the true underlying network structures with high sensitivity (Fried & Eskamp, 2018) and has been used in previous studies examining belief networks (Turner-Zwinkels et al., 2022). We also explored how beliefs clustered together using community detection methods. We applied an agglomerative walktrap algorithm from the igraph package (Csárdi, 2021) to identify densely connected communities using random walks (Pons & Latapy, 2005). We selected this algorithm given its ability to accurately recover network communities (Hoffman et al., 2017) and its use in studying belief networks (Quintana, 2023;Turner-Zwinkels et al., 2021;2022).

From this network, we calculated the eigenvector centrality for each belief node as a measure of centrality. To validate centrality as a metric to compare and identify promising beliefs, we examined the correlation between node centrality and the average correlation between the belief and voting intention. We focused on eigenvector centrality as a measure of centrality because it reflects not only the number of connections but how influential connections are, reflecting greater potential impact if targeted. Furthermore, while researchers should use caution when inferring causal importance from centrality measures, eigenvector centrality predicts the actual causal influence of nodes reasonably well (Dablander & Hinne, 2019). Correlational values were Fisher z-transformed and the absolute value was used since eigenvector centrality does not take into account the sign of relationships.

div.head: Correlations with voting intentions
div.p: All beliefs showed statistically significant correlations with intention to vote and statistically significant mean differences between intenders and non-intenders. Negative correlations ranged from r = -.71 ("Voting is not important to me") to r = -.26 ("Not voting is a form of self-expression") and positive correlations ranged from r = .35 ("Voting makes me feel connected to others") to r = .58 ("Voting is relevant to me personally"). Correlations for promising beliefs with >20% to gain (see below) are reported in Table 3; correlations for all beliefs are reported in Supplementary Table S3.

div.head: Percentage to move
div.p: The most common strongly held beliefs (i.e., beliefs participants strongly agreed or strongly disagreed with) were "voting is my right" (percentage to move = 28.5) and "the outcome of the election will impact the future of our country" (percentage to move = 43.8). All other beliefs were strongly held by less than half of the sample (Table S2), indicating substantial room to move.

div.head: Percentage to gain
div.p: Percentage to gain ranged from 11.2%-28.5%, and 29 beliefs had percentage to gain values >20%, which we used as a threshold to identify "promising beliefs" to target in messaging. Four of the top five most promising beliefs were related behavioral beliefs related to the self ("Voting is consistent with my core values", "Voting is not important to me") and disillusionment ("It doesn't matter if I personally vote", "The system is too broken to be fixed by voting"). Percentage to gain values and descriptive statistics for the promising beliefs are reported in Table 3 and for the remaining beliefs in Supplementary Table S3.

div.head: Belief network
div.p: Network structure. Applying a community detection algorithm revealed a moderately modular structure (modularity = 0.47) with five clusters (Figure 1A) roughly corresponding to: (1) control beliefs (e.g., "It's too difficult to find out how to register to vote"), ( 2) normative beliefs about belonging (e.g., "Voting makes me feel like I'm part of a community"), (3) behavioral beliefs about the instrumentality of voting (e.g., "Voting is a way I can express my voice about issues I care about", "Voting is a way to contribute to building a better world"), (4) behavioral beliefs about the impact of the election and relevance of voting (e.g., "Voting impacts policies and outcomes I care about", "Voting affects the rights and freedoms of people I care about"), and ( 5) negative behavioral beliefs (e.g., "If I don't like the candidates, it's not worth voting") and beliefs related to the importance of voting (e.g., "It doesn't matter if I personally vote", "Voting is consistent with my core values").

Descriptively examining the beliefs within each cluster revealed several interesting insights. First, the clusters containing control beliefs and normative beliefs about belonging each contained beliefs of a single type, whereas the other clusters contained a combination of normative and behavioral beliefs. Second, the latter clusters contained a mix of self-related (e.g., "There is a lot at stake for me personally") and social behavioral beliefs (e.g., "There is a lot at stake for people I care about"). Third, self-related and social beliefs within these clusters were not segregated but were instead often tightly linked (e.g., "Voting will affect my rights and freedoms" and "Voting will impact my local community"). Fourth, although normative beliefs tended to be more strongly associated with other normative or social beliefs within these clusters, there were some surprisingly strong connections with self-related behavioral beliefs (e.g., "Voting is my duty" and "Voting is consistent with my core values").

We quantified the number of connections between communities to examine their interrelationships and found substantial variability. Clusters 4 (behavioral beliefs about impact) and 5 (negative beliefs and beliefs about importance) had the most connections (n = 15), whereas clusters 4 and 2 (belonging beliefs), clusters 4 and 1 (control beliefs), and clusters 1 and 2 had no connections. Cluster 5 had connections to all other clusters (n cluster 1 = 9, n cluster 2 = 1, n cluster 3 = 10), and Cluster 3 (instrumental beliefs) was moderately connected to other all clusters (n cluster 1 = 5, n cluster 2 = 5, n cluster 4 = 7).

Belief centrality. Averaging across beliefs in each cluster, behavioral beliefs about the impact of the election and relevance of voting tended to be most central ( M = 0.83; Figure 1B). Overall, "Voting is relevant to me personally" was the most central belief and numerous other beliefs associated with self-relevance (e.g., voting affecting one's rights and freedoms, voting being consistent with one's core values, voting not being personally important, etc.) also tended to be more central. Behavioral beliefs about the instrumentality of voting ( M = 0.68), normative beliefs about belonging ( M = 0.65) and behavioral beliefs about the importance of voting ( M = 0.58), were less central, and control beliefs ( M = 0.44) were the least central. In addition to control beliefs, negative behavioral beliefs related to disillusionment (e.g., "Not voting is a form of self-expression", "The system is too broken to be fixed by voting") tended to be the least central.

Association between belief centrality and correlation with intention to vote. Examining the relationship between belief node centrality and the mean absolute correlation between beliefs and voting intentions revealed a strong correlation (Figure 1C). Beliefs that were more central also tended to be more strongly correlated with intentions to vote ( r (35) = .62, 95% CI [.37, .79], t = 4.70, p < .001).

Associations between belief centrality and percentage to move and to gain. In contrast to the correlations with intentions to vote, belief centrality was weakly negatively associated with percentage to move ( r (35) = -.20, 95% CI [-.49, .13], t = 1.20, p = .238) but the relationship was not statistically significant. The correlation between belief centrality and percentage to gain was near zero ( r (35) = .03, 95% CI [-.30, .35], t = 0.17, p = .867). Although centrality and percentage to gain were not correlated, we examined areas of correspondence between these two methods by identifying beliefs that were above average for both centrality and percentage to gain (Figure S1; Table 4).
