div.head: Discussion
div.p: Study 1 surveyed college students to identify promising beliefs about voting to target via social media messaging. Voting beliefs ranged from being moderately to highly correlated with voting intentions and the majority of beliefs were not strongly held, indicating substantial potential to strengthen voting beliefs in this population. We used the Hornik & Woolf method to calculate the percentage to gain-that is, the possible increase in people who intend to vote (i.e., endorse "strongly agree") that could be achieved if everyone strongly held the belief. We identified 29 beliefs that had more than 20% to gain. These beliefs were from across belief categories, highlighting that there are numerous pathways to target voting beliefs through messaging.

Although the percentage to gain was the metric we used to inform message development in this project-that is, in the subsequent studies in this paper-we also conducted post-hoc analyses examining the structure of the voting belief network to inform future message development. We found that belief centrality and correlation with intentions were robustly related; beliefs with higher eigenvector centrality also tended to have higher average correlations with voting intentions. Given the strength of the correlation, considering belief centrality could provide a complementary method to determine which beliefs to target in messaging campaigns.

In this sample, behavioral beliefs about the personal importance of voting and the self-related and social consequences of the election tended to be most central, whereas control beliefs and negative behavioral beliefs related to disillusionment tended to be the least central. This suggests that messages that help people identify why voting is relevant to themselves and how the outcome of the election will impact themselves and their communities have greater potential to increase voting intentions because the underlying beliefs can activate other influential beliefs, strengthening the overall effect.

Although belief centrality was strongly associated with belief-voting intention correlations, it was not associated with percentage to gain. The percentage to gain metric combines information about strength of the relationship with intention (i.e., its correlation) but also how commonly held the belief is (i.e., the percentage to move). How central beliefs are was strongly related to the correlation with intention to vote but only weakly related to percentage to move, and this relationship was negative. This suggests that beliefs that are more central may also be somewhat more common. This underscores the usefulness of the Hornik & Woolf method, yet also suggests that formative research can gain unique insights from incorporating network approaches in tandem to identify influential beliefs that still have room to move.

div.head: Study 2: Message co-design and testing
div.p: The goal of this study was to develop nonpartisan, youth-focused GOTV messages targeting promising voting beliefs identified in Study 1 using the Hornik and Woolf method. In order to create messages that would be effective for college students, we used a participatory co-design process to develop the messages with undergraduate researchers on our team. Participatory approaches acknowledge lived experience as a form of expertise and seek to center it in research (Cornish et al., 2023;Ozer et al., 2024). Supporting the population of interest to shape the research can increase its potential to generate impactful and implementable solutions (Mansbridge, 2019). We adopted a similar approach to other youth-focused message co-design studies (Kikut-Stein et al., 2024;Kikut-Stein et al., 2025) and iteratively designed and refined nonpartisan GOTV messages using online message testing.

We conducted this study in two phases with two samples. In the Message development sample, we recruited a national sample of college students via the Prolific platform to quickly test a large set of initial messages. Based on this initial testing, we then refined the messages and tested a subset of the messages in a sample from our target population-college students at the University of Pennsylvania (Message testing sample). In both samples, participants viewed messages and rated perceived argument strength, nonpartisanship, and the correspondence between each message and targeted beliefs.

div.head: Message development sample
div.p: The first round of message development took place via an online survey administered via Qualtrics with participants recruited from Prolific ( N = 126), an online labor marketplace. Inclusion criteria were as follows: current college students in the U.S., aged 18-22 years, fluent in English, and eligible to vote in the November 2024 general election. The mean age of respondents was 20.7 (SD = 1.3). The distribution of self-reported gender identity was as follows: 47.6% men, 45.2% women, 0% genderqueer, 4.8% non-binary, 0.8% preferred not to say, and 0.8% preferred to self-describe. With respect to race and ethnicity, participants identified as the following: 47.8% White, 8.0% East Asian, 22.5% Black or African American, 2.2% South Asian, 4.3% Southeast Asian, 2.2% Middle Eastern or North African, 3.6% American Indian or Alaskan Native, 2.2% Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander, and 3.6% other racial/ethnic identity. 19.0% of participants also identified as Hispanic or Latina/o/x. This study was approved by the University of Pennsylvania Institutional Review Board and participants gave informed consent. Participants were compensated $2 for completing a 10-minute survey.

div.head: Message testing sample
div.p: The second round of message testing took place via an online survey administered via Qualtrics that recruited students at the University of Pennsylvania ( N = 198). Inclusion criteria were as follows: current undergraduate students at the University of Pennsylvania, aged 18+, fluent in English, and eligible to vote in the November 2024 general election. One person was excluded for being >25 years old and 8 people were excluded due to technical errors that led them to be unable to view the images, yielding a final sample of N = 189. Participants in this sample were aged 18-22 ( M = 19.7, SD = 1.2). Regarding gender, participants self-identified as the following: 27.5% men, 69.8% women, 1.1% genderqueer, 0% non-binary, and 1.6% preferred not to say. With respect to race and ethnicity, participants identified as the following: 47.5% White, 23.2% East Asian, 8.6% Black or African American, 10.1% South Asian, 3.5% Southeast Asian, 1.0% Middle Eastern or North African, and 2.0% other racial/ethnic identity. 15.9% of participants also identified as Hispanic or Latina/o/x. This study was approved by the University of Pennsylvania Institutional Review Board and participants gave informed consent. Participants were compensated via course credit for completing a 15-minute survey.

div.head: Written message co-creation
div.p: We iteratively and collaboratively developed messages targeting promising beliefs identified in Study 1. Research team members each chose 2-4 promising beliefs and brainstormed two messages for each belief. Ideas were not limited to text-based messages but also included visual arguments (e.g., short comics or single-panel illustrations). In line with Hornik & Woolf method, we only targeted beliefs that we determined could plausibly be changed by messaging campaigns. Targeted beliefs are highlighted in Figure 1C. We then refined the messages through an iterative process of review and revision. Overall, we aimed to develop a set of nonpartisan messages that covered a broad range of beliefs and topics.

div.head: Visual message co-creation
div.p: We adapted the message text to create visuals for use on social media. A research team member with expertise in visual design developed images using Canva, an online design tool. The key features that were considered during adaptation included the target audience (young adults), demographic diversity (e.g., with respect to race, ethnicity, and gender), visual accessibility (e.g., colors with enough contrast to be seen clearly by most viewers), appropriate visual themes (images that symbolize voting, civic engagement, etc.). Images were then iteratively refined in response to feedback from the research team. The initial stimulus set used in the Message development sample contained 29 messages. After initial testing, three additional messages that combined informational and persuasive elements from other messages were developed for testing in the Message testing sample. All messages and alternative text can be found online: https://osf.io/axrc7.

div.head: Message development sample
div.p: At the beginning of the online survey, participants provided informed consent and were then shown 12 messages. Messages were separated into four thematic groups for presentation in the survey-self, social, duty and response efficacy, and informational-and participants saw a random sample of 3 messages from each group. For each message, participants rated perceived argument strength (Zhao et al., 2011), nonpartisanship, and message alignment with the beliefs it was designed to target. Perceived argument strength was assessed with nine items using a 5-point Likert-type agreement scale (1 = Strongly disagree, 5 = Strongly agree) or a 5-point Likert-type strength scale (1 = Very weak, 5 = Very strong) for statement strength. Nonpartisanship was measured using a single item ("This statement is nonpartisan"; 1 = Strongly disagree, 5 = Strongly agree). Belief alignment was measured by asking participants to rate their agreement that "This message makes me believe…" for a set of beliefs using a 7-point Likert-type scale (1 = Strongly disagree, 7 = Strongly agree). Beliefs were grouped such that only beliefs related to the message thematic group were presented for each message. Each category included 3-5 beliefs; examples include: "There is a lot at stake for me personally in the election" ( self group); "Voting allows me to be a part of something bigger than myself" ( social group); "The system is too broken to be fixed by voting" ( duty and response efficacy group); "It's too difficult or effortful to make a plan to vote" ( informational group). After rating the messages, participants reported demographics and completed individual difference measures not discussed in this paper.

div.head: Message testing sample
div.p: A similar procedure was used to test a set of 14 messages, which were selected and refined based on the results from the Message development sample. Twelve messages from the Message development sample were selected based on the message effectiveness criteria outlined in the following paragraph. Three new messages were created that blended information about how to vote from the informational messages with persuasive content from social messages that were not selected. However, due to a technical error, one of these new messages was not presented, resulting in a total of 14 messages. For randomization purposes, these messages were separated into two groups in the survey-one that combined self and duty messages, and one that combined social and response efficacy messages. Participants were presented with a random sample of five messages from each group for a total of 10 messages. For each message, they followed the same rating procedure as in Study 2a.

div.head: Determining message effectiveness
div.p: We evaluated the effectiveness of the messages by considering ratings of nonpartisanship, argument strength and belief strength. First, we excluded messages rated as somewhat partisan (i.e., the average nonpartisan rating was below the midpoint of the scale disagreeing that the message was nonpartisan; n = 1 in the Message development sample). Then, we created a composite score integrating argument and target belief strength. Because we sought to identify messages that induced targeted beliefs and made strong, persuasive arguments about voting, we used a multiplicative approach (i.e., multiplying argument and belief strength) requiring both dimensions to be high to achieve a high score.

div.head: Associations between promising belief metrics and message effectiveness
div.p: Building on the results from Study 1 showing that percentage to gain and belief centrality might both be used to guide message development, we conducted post-hoc analyses examining relationships between these metrics for the beliefs targeted in each message and message effectiveness. We combined data from the Message development and testing samples and averaged centrality and percentage to gain across all beliefs targeted in each message to get a single value for each, per message. We then fit linear mixed effects models regressing message effectiveness on all potential models including the fixed effects of centrality and percentage to gain and used model comparison to select best fitting models. Results for the composite score are reported in the main manuscript and results for argument and belief strength are reported in Supplementary Material along with detailed methods.

div.head: Message development sample
div.p: The goal of this analysis was to select a set of 15 messages that could be used in subsequent message testing in our target audience-college students at the University of Pennsylvania (Message testing sample). Messages were ranked by message effectiveness score to guide selection (Figure 2). Overall, self-related messages targeting behavioral beliefs about the impact, importance, and instrumentality of voting tended to be the most effective (Table 3). Notably, informational messages targeting control beliefs were the least effective. Because these messages did not include persuasive arguments, we generated three new messages that combined information about how to vote with persuasive elements from social messages targeting normative beliefs about belonging for testing in the Message testing sample. To create a set of 15 messages, we selected the 12 messages with the highest message effectiveness scores, which included self-related ( n = 7), social ( n = 2), response efficacy ( n = 2), and duty ( n = 1) messages. Mean nonpartisan ratings, argument strength ratings, belief strength ratings, and composite scores for individual messages are reported in Supplementary Material (Table S6).

div.head: Message testing sample
div.p: Descriptives All messages (Figure 3A) were rated as nonpartisan (M range = 3.46 -4.17). Descriptively, self-related messages targeting behavioral beliefs about the impact of the election (e.g., self_2: "The outcome of the election will impact these issues for better or worse… vote to have a say in what happens.") made the strongest arguments ( M = 3.83, SD = 0.73 ) , followed by messages targeting: behavioral beliefs about the importance of voting (e.g., efficacy_6: "Myth: Voting doesn't matter if I'm not in a swing state. Fact: 33 states have Senate seats open and every state has Representative seats open -the ballot is more than a presidential election!") and negative beliefs (e.g., efficacy_3: "If your vote doesn't matter, no one's does. Every vote counts!"; M = 3.67, SD = 0.80), behavioral beliefs about the instrumentality of voting (e.g., self_1: "Do you care about ___? Voting is a way to express concerns on an issue together."; M = 3.43, SD = 0.81), and the combined messages targeting control and belonging beliefs (e.g., "Voting is confusing! It's easier to make sense of it together. Share this step-by-step guide with people you care about! usa.gov/how-to-vote"; M = 3.24, SD = 0.85). A similar order was observed for belief strength: impact beliefs ( M = 5.42, SD = 1.37), instrumentality beliefs ( M = 5.08, SD = 1.44), control + belonging beliefs ( M = 4.06, SD = 1.65), and importance/negative beliefs ( M = 3.29, SD = 1.95).

div.head: Selection
div.p: The goal of this analysis was to select the five best performing messages to use in a subsequent message experiment (Study 3). As in the Message development sample, messages were ranked and selected based on the message effectiveness scores (Figure 3B). However, two messages in the top five targeting self-related beliefs (self_1 and self_3) were very similar. We therefore selected the simpler of these two messages along with the sixth most effective message to test in Study 3.

div.head: Associations between promising belief metrics and message effectiveness
div.p: Post-hoc analyses showed that percentage to gain and belief centrality were each uniquely positively associated with message effectiveness scores (Table S8; Figure S2). However, the relationship with belief centrality was approximately 2.5 times stronger (𝛽 = 0.44, 95% CI [0.28, 0.59], t (28.05) = 5.87, p < .001) than with percentage to gain (𝛽 = 0.17, 95% CI [0.01, 0.34], t (26.81) = 2.14, p = .042). All statistics from this model, the models including argument and belief strength as outcomes, and model comparison metrics are reported in Supplementary Material Tables S7-8. Belief text is abbreviated for visualization purposes. Alternative text for messages can be found in Table S5.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In Study 2, we developed and validated nonpartisan GOTV messages targeting promising beliefs identified in Study 1. We assessed message effectiveness in terms of argument (i.e., persuasiveness and effectiveness at motivating voting) and belief strength (i.e., elicitation of the promising belief targeted). In the Message development sample-a national sample of college students-self-related messages targeting behavioral beliefs about the self-relevance (e.g., "Voting is relevant to me personally") and instrumentality of voting (e.g., "Voting is a way I can advance the causes I care about") tended to be most effective, whereas informational messages targeting control beliefs ("It's too difficult or effortful to make a plan to vote") were the least effective. The effectiveness of messages targeting beliefs about duty (e.g., "Voting is my duty"), response efficacy (e.g., "Because of where I live and vote, my vote doesn't matter"), and belonging (e.g., "Voting makes me feel like I'm part of a community") were more variable.

Testing the subset of most effective messages from the Message developmental sample (and new messages targeting informational and social belonging beliefs together) in a local sample of college students revealed similar results. Even when combined with social themes, informational messages targeting control beliefs tended to perform the worst, both with respect to argument and belief strength. This is noteworthy given that prior research has explained low youth voter turnout in terms of informational barriers about how to vote (e.g., Feldman et al., 2007;McDevitt & Chaffee, 2000;Syvertsen et al., 2009;Bergan et al., 2021;Bennion and Nickerson, 2016;McKinney & Banwart, 2005). This suggests that while information is necessary-particularly among youth who have not had the opportunity to develop voting habits-it may not be sufficient to shift control beliefs about voting in ways that affect downstream voting intentions. From this sample, we selected five of the best performing messages to test in a subsequent message experiment.

We also conducted post-hoc analyses combining across samples to explore whether and how strongly promising belief metrics identified in Study 1 were related to message effectiveness ratings. We found that messages targeting beliefs with higher percentages to gain and centrality were also rated as more effective. Percentage to gain and centrality each independently predicted message effectiveness, highlighting their utility as complementary measures. However, belief centrality was more strongly associated with message effectiveness than percentage to gain, and also predicted both argument and belief strength, whereas percentage to gain only predicted belief strength. Together, these findings establish links between promising belief metrics and subsequent message effectiveness perceptions and further demonstrate the potential for network approaches to guide campaign development.

div.head: Study 3: Message experiment
div.p: In Study 3, we conducted an experiment with two primary aims. First, we sought to test the effectiveness of the co-designed GOTV messages targeting promising beliefs compared to existing youth-focused GOTV messages on social media from both national and local campaigns. Second, we sought to assess how well the GOTV messages co-designed with and for undergraduates our university would generalize to a national sample of college students. We chose to prioritize ecological validity over tight experimental control and selected existing messages on social media from Rock the Vote as national message controls. We focused on Rock the Vote because it is one of the oldest and best established nonpartisan national organizations focused on youth voter engagement and has substantial reach (Rock the Vote, 2025). Although our co-designed messages were persuasive, we also included informational messages since providing youth with voting information is a common strategy in youth-focused campaigns (e.g., Bennion & Michelson, 2023, Feldman et al., 2007;McKinney & Banwart, 2005) and generic messages (e.g., an image of an "I voted" sticker) as a low-level control.

In our primary analyses, we predicted that across message types participants would rate the co-designed messages targeting promising voting beliefs ( co-designed messages ) as more motivating, persuasive, and self-relevant than messages from Rock the Vote ( control messages ). Considering each type of message separately, we expected that the co-designed messages would be more motivating, persuasive, and self-relevant than informational and generic control messages and at least or more motivating, persuasive, and self-relevant than persuasive control messages. To evaluate the impact of developing messages for our local audience using formative research, we also conducted supplementary analyses using existing messages generated by students from our GOTV partner organization as controls. The hypotheses and the analysis plan were preregistered before data collection ( https://osf.io/4jdxh ).

div.head: Power
div.p: Our target sample size was determined by an a priori power analysis and found that a sample of 250 participants would be sufficient to detect a within-person condition difference (i.e., co-designed versus control messages) for an effect size of Cohen's d = 0.1 with >80% power and d = 0.15 with >99% power. We collected two samples-one local sample of students at our university and one national sample of college students-and aimed to recruit 250 participants in each. However, given the short timeline between the study launch and election day, we were only able to recruit 73 participants in the local sample. For this sample, we were powered to detect an effect of d = 0.17 with >80% power.

div.head: Participants
div.p: In the Local sample, participants ( N = 72) were recruited from the student participant pool at the University of Pennsylvania and were eligible to participate if they were 18 or older, eligible to vote in the 2024 U.S. general election, and had not participated in Study 2. In the National sample, participants ( N = 251) were recruited from Prolific and were eligible to participate if they were college students in the U.S. between the ages of 18-22 and eligible to vote in the 2024 U.S. general election. Two participants in the national sample were excluded from analysis for reporting they were older than 25 (final N = 249).

Participants' ages were similar across the two samples (Local sample: M = 20.2, SD = 1.3; National sample: M = 20.4, SD = 1.4). In the Local sample, participants reported the following gender identities: 59.7% women, 38.9% men, 0% genderqueer, 0% non-binary, 1.4% preferred not to say, 0% preferred to self describe. The gender distribution was similar in the National sample: 57.0% women, 36.5% men, 0% genderqueer, 4.4% non-binary, 0.4% preferred not to say, 0.4% preferred to self describe.

In the Local sample, participants reported the following racial identities: 47.4% White, 22.4% East Asian, 11.8% Black or African American, 7.9% South Asian, 5.3% Southeast Asian, 2.6% Middle Eastern or North African, 0% American Indian or Alaskan Native, 0% other racial/ethnic identity not listed, 0% Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander). In addition, 8.3% of participants identified as Hispanic or Latina/o/x. The National sample included fewer Asian participants and more Black participants than the Local sample: 49.5% White, 10.1% East Asian, 21.3% Black or African American, 3.5% South Asian, 6.6% Southeast Asian, 1.0% Middle Eastern or North African, 2.4% American Indian or Alaskan Native, 3.1% other racial/ethnic identity, 0.7% Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander. In addition, more participants (19.3%) identified as Hispanic or Latina/o/x.

This study was approved by the University of Pennsylvania Institutional Review Board and participants gave informed consent. Participants in the Local sample were compensated via course credit for completing a 15-minute survey and participants in the National sample were compensated $2 for completing a 10-minute survey.

div.head: Procedure
div.p: For this experiment we used a within-subjects design in which each participant rated a subset of messages from all conditions. The experiment included two primary message types across both samples: messages targeting promising beliefs, co-designed with youth (co-designed messages) and a set of messages from a national nonpartisan GOTV organization, Rock the Vote (control messages). The control messages enabled us to compare our experimental messages with ecologically-valid, existing messages that also targeted youth but were presumably designed without insights from youth partners and formative research. In the Local sample, we also tested the co-designed messages against messages previously created and disseminated by our partner organization, Penn Leads the Vote (PLTV), that were designed by youth but did not target promising beliefs identified in formative research ("student control messages"). Results from these secondary analyses are reported in the Supplemental Material.

The co-designed messages consisted of 5 messages selected from Study 2 targeting beliefs about the self-relevance of voting (self-related beliefs) and the belief that an individual's vote matters (response efficacy beliefs). These messages aimed to influence participants' attitudes toward voting by highlighting personal significance and the impact of one's vote. Control messages were categorized as either generic messages (e.g., "Vote Vote Vote!" or images of "I voted" stickers), informational messages (messages that provide helpful instructions, such as how to complete mail-in ballots), or persuasive messages (messages that aim to motivate action by making an argument, e.g., "If you don't register, you can't vote. Which means you don't get a say in our democracy."). The control messages across both samples were derived from Rock the Vote 's Instagram posts shared between June and October of 2024. We selected 15 control messages that met the following criteria: (a) nonpartisan content, (b) classification as either generic, informational, or persuasive, (c) not targeting specific groups (e.g., Black voters or women voters), (d) not referencing expired deadlines (e.g., past voter registration deadlines), and (e) standalone graphics without captions or additional information. The 15 control messages included 5 generic messages, 5 informational messages, and 5 persuasive messages. All messages and alternative text can be found online: https://osf.io/axrc7 .

In both samples, participants viewed the same set of 5 co-designed messages, as well as a random subset of 5 control messages sampled from the set of 15. All messages were presented in a randomized order. Participants used a sliding scale (0 = strongly disagree, 100 = strongly agree) to rate each message on three primary outcome measures: motivation to vote ("This message motivates me to vote"), persuasiveness ("This message is persuasive"), and self-relevance ("This message is relevant to me"). They also rated the messages on additional measures, described in Supplementary Material.

div.head: Statistical analyses
div.p: Our primary analyses tested the effect of message source (co-designed or control) on message motivation to vote, persuasiveness, and self-relevance collapsed across message types (persuasive, informational, or generic). For each outcome, we fit a separate linear mixed effects model regressing the dependent variable on the fixed effect of message source and intercepts were allowed to vary randomly across participants. To test whether the effect of message source varied by message type, we fit the same models within each message type separately. We checked each model for modeling assumption violations, including normality of residuals and heteroskedasticity. No assumptions were violated and no data transformations were performed. As preregistered, we did not exclude or transform any outliers. We conducted exploratory analyses to examine generalizability of messages from local to national samples by including sample and its interaction with message source as fixed effects. The following additional analyses are reported in Supplementary Material: preregistered secondary analyses examining student-generated control messages and sharing and emotions ratings across samples; sensitivity analyses controlling for aesthetic quality and nonpartisanship; and exploratory message-level analyses.

div.head: Descriptive statistics
div.p: Means and standard deviations for our primary outcomes are reported for each sample separately in Table 5. Descriptive statistics for all outcomes are reported in Table S9-10.

div.head: Primary analyses
div.p: Across message types, we predicted that the co-designed messages targeting promising voting beliefs would be more motivating, persuasive, and self-relevant than control messages from Rock the Vote . We found strong evidence for all three hypotheses (Table 3). Compared to control messages, the co-designed messages were substantially more motivating ( b = 14.58, 95% CI [12.97,16.19]) and persuasive ( b = 16.68,95% CI [15.03,18.32]), and moderately more self-relevant ( b = 6.70, 95% CI [5.18, 8.24]). Examining potential differences between message types, we found as expected that the co-designed messages were more motivating and persuasive than generic, informational, and persuasive control messages. However, the co-designed messages were only more self-relevant than generic and persuasive control messages but not informational control messages. Statistics for all models are reported in Table 3. Sensitivity analyses controlling for nonpartisanship and aesthetic quality of the messages slightly weakened the magnitude of the experimental effects, but all remained statistically significant (Table S12). Message-level effects are reported in Supplementary Material (Figure S3). 320 (2833.93)
Note. The reference level for Source is the control messages and the local sample for Sample.

div.head: Student control message analyses
div.p: In the Local sample, we also compared our co-designed messages targeting promising voting beliefs against prior messages created independently by the student-led GOTV organization on campus who we partnered with as a set of secondary control messages. In line with preregistered hypotheses, compared to student messages created without a theoretical framework across message types, the co-designed messages were more motivating ( b = 8.03, 95% CI [4.87,11.18], t (613.36) = 5.00, p < .001) and persuasive ( b = 11.00, 95% CI [7.51,14.49], t (618.07) = 6.19, p < .001), and similarly were self-relevant ( b = -2.83, 95% CI [-5.99, 0.33], t (622.49) = 1.76, p = .080). Model statistics and the results for each message type separately are included in more detail in Supplemental Materials (Table S13).

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In Study 3, we used a within-subject experimental design to determine the degree to which co-designing GOTV messages targeting promising voting beliefs in partnership with the target population increased message-related motivation, persuasion and self-relevance. We found evidence of substantial benefits to conducting formative research and tailoring messages to promising beliefs relevant to the target population. We also found that our co-designed messages were more motivating and persuasive than prior messages that were designed by members of the target population (via our student-led, campus partner) but without drawing on evidence-based insights from formative research. Therefore, these results highlight the importance of integrating theory-driven formative research with participatory co-design practices with members of the target population, to develop effective GOTV messages.

div.head: General discussion
div.p: Despite expressing high levels of political concern, young adults remain underrepresented at the polls. This work sought to develop effective communication strategies to address this longstanding gap in young Americans' civic life. Across three studies, we integrated formative research methods with a participatory co-design approach to develop and test get-out-the-vote (GOTV) messages targeting youth-specific voting beliefs. In the first study, we mapped beliefs associated with voting and identified promising beliefs that were strongly correlated with voting intentions and had the greatest opportunities for belief change through communication campaigns using standard methods. In exploratory network analyses, we also considered the relationships among these beliefs and demonstrated that network methods can be used as a complementary approach to identify influential beliefs in formative research. In the second study, we iteratively co-designed and tested messages to develop a set of messages that effectively targeted promising beliefs. Finally, the third study demonstrated that in both local and national samples, our top co-designed messages targeting key promising beliefs about the personal relevance and impact of voting were consistently rated as more motivating, persuasive, and personally relevant than messages designed by a prominent national youth-focused GOTV organization, Rock the Vote, and as more motivating and persuasive than prior messages made by our local student-led GOTV organization partner. Together, these findings illustrate the promise of integrating theory-driven, formative research and human-centered, participatory approaches to develop messaging campaigns.

div.head: Formative research to identify promising voting beliefs
div.p: Building on standard message campaign development frameworks (Fishbein & Capella, 2006), this project used two novel approaches to conduct formative research-participatory elicitation methods to generate beliefs and network analyses to identify influential beliefs. Our research was grounded in the Reasoned Action Approach and Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB; Fishbein & Ajzen, 2010;Ajzen, 1991). Prior work has applied TPB to youth voting, but used single-item summary measures assessing attitudes, social norms, and perceived behavioral control and did not consider upstream beliefs shaping these perceptions (Glasford, 2008). Other work has considered beliefs about voting but has not systematically compared them in the context of TPB. We addressed these gaps by generating a large battery of beliefs through a participatory research process with student partners. Although many of these beliefs could be classified as control, normative, or behavioral beliefs, others were more nuanced and cut across categories (e.g., beliefs about social impacts of the election)-which was reflected in the network analysis, showing a mix of normative and behavioral beliefs in several clusters. While TPB does not define belief categories as mutually exclusive, these results highlight the importance of considering relationships among beliefs and suggest that data-driven network approaches can inform message design according to principles such as network control or activation spillover (Brandt & Sleegers, 2021).

The nuanced set of beliefs elicited in formative research was made possible by our student partner's input and led to the identification of numerous promising voting beliefs that could be targeted in GOTV messaging. Indeed, many of these beliefs had substantial percentages to gain compared to benchmarks from other studies (Hornik et al., 2019;Yang et al., 2023;Brennan et al., 2013). These beliefs were also aligned with prior work, highlighting voting beliefs relating to election consequences (Bali et al., 2020), self-relevance (Knoester & Kretz, 2017), efficacy (Harder & Krosnick, 2008;Condon & Holleque, 2013), knowledge and information (Maiello et al., 2003;Harder & Krosnick, 2008;Knoester & Kretz, 2017;Knoester & Gichiru, 2021;Kawashima-Ginsburg and Kiesa, 2019;Bergan et al., 2021;CIRCLE, 2022), sense of duty (Bali et al., 2020;Lydic et al., 2025;Harder & Krosnick, 2008;Blais & Daoust, 2020), and normative beliefs (Harder & Krosnick, 2008;Bali et al., 2020;Glynn et al., 2009;Bergan et al., 2021).

Although we relied on the Hornik and Woolf method to identify promising beliefs prior to message development, we also demonstrate the utility of using network methods to identify influential beliefs. Considering the relationships among beliefs was motivated in part by the observation that messages targeting less promising beliefs can still be effective if they are correlated with more promising beliefs (Lee et al., 2016). We found that belief centrality was positively associated with correlations with voting intentions, suggesting its viability as a metric to identify promising beliefs. Critically, belief centrality and percentage to gain were not correlated and some beliefs had notable discrepancies between these metrics. In particular, control beliefs and negative beliefs related to disillusionment had high percentages to gain, but low centrality. These messages also tended to be the least effective in Study 2, underscoring that belief centrality may add value beyond standard methods. In line with this, we also found that the most effective messages targeted beliefs with high network centrality. Direct comparisons of percentage to gain and belief centrality further reinforced this idea by showing that belief centrality was a stronger predictor of message effectiveness than belief centrality. Based on these results, future research can be designed to more explicitly test the following predictions: compared to messages targeting less central beliefs, messages targeting more central beliefs should be more effective and more strongly influence other beliefs leading to greater network-level belief change. Future research can also compare the utility of percentage to gain and network centrality to guide message development by comparing messages targeting beliefs with high percentage to gain but low centrality and vice versa.

div.head: Message effects
div.p: Many of the promising beliefs we identified were amenable to being targeted in nonpartisan messaging. Mirroring the results from our formative research, the most effective messages aimed to help people identify why voting is relevant to them, why their vote matters, and how the outcome of the election might affect them and people they care about. For example, the two most effective messages included "myth-busting" the insignificance of one's vote and encouraging the audience to connect voting to one's values without specifying particular policy positions. In contrast, social and informational messages about registering and voting were less effective, even when combined. We observed further evidence in the message experiment that informational messages are perceived as self-relevant but not motivating. This is an important insight because information and knowledge barriers are consistently highlighted in youth voting research (Maiello et al., 2003;Harder & Krosnick, 2008;Knoester & Kretz, 2017;Knoester & Gichiru, 2021;Kawashima-Ginsburg and Kiesa, 2019;Bergan et al., 2021;CIRCLE, 2022), are frequently discussed in social media messaging (Ad Council, 2020), and may feel like safer targets for nonpartisan GOTV organizations and nonprofits that must avoid perceptions of partisanship (Alliance for Justice, 2024; Nonprofit VOTE, 2024). Our findings demonstrate that GOTV messages can be motivating when targeting beliefs about the personal relevance of voting without evoking partisan cues and without focusing on single issues. By naming multiple issues and without specifying positions about them, these messages struck a balance between persuasiveness and nonpartisanship.

Co-designing these messages in partnership with students from the student-led, nonpartisan GOTV organization on campus (PLTV) in ways that combined their expertise with theory-driven frameworks increased message effectiveness. By integrating insights from behavior change and communication theory with lived experience and local knowledge from student partners, we developed messages that successfully targeted promising beliefs. This co-design process created messages that were perceived as more motivating, persuasive, and self-relevant than existing social media messages from Rock the Vote, a national nonpartisan GOTV organization aimed at (but not directed by) youth. We also found that our co-designed messages were more effective than messages previously created by our partner organization, PLTV (i.e., messages that were designed by youth but were not theory-driven and did not aim to target promising beliefs). Although we do not know how the Rock the Vote messages were developed (i.e., whether they were evidence-based or had input from youth) and therefore cannot make inferences about specific mechanisms, our findings demonstrate that the integration of theory-driven formative research and participatory co-design practices in partnership with the target audience is a fruitful framework for campaign development (Kikut-Stein et al. 2024a;2024b). More broadly, this framework dovetails with recent calls to leverage youth expertise in the design and implementation of research-based GOTV interventions for more effective tailoring and to support youth civic engagement (Cosme et al., Under review.;Michelson & Ostfeld, 2024).

Critically, the co-design process created messages that were effective in our local context but also generalized beyond it. We found that the co-designed messages were equally effective in a national sample of college students, indicating that the promising beliefs we identified and the messages we developed targeting them were broadly relevant to college students. This finding is consistent with recent work applying YPAR approaches in health communication showing formative research and message development conducted locally can generalize nationally (Kikut-Stein et al, 2024b). This evidence underscores the feasibility of using this approach to develop GOTV messaging campaigns that can be implemented locally while simultaneously generating generalizable scientific knowledge.

div.head: Theoretical implications
div.p: These findings advance theory in political communication in several ways. First, it establishes the use of belief centrality as a complementary method for identifying promising beliefs to target in communication interventions and messaging campaigns. It extends gold-standard approaches like the Hornik and Woolf method to take into account relationships among beliefs-a previously identified limitation (Lee et al., 2016)-and provides a similarly actionable ranking metric to guide belief selection and message design. Second, the data-driven network analyses add nuance to Reasoned Action Approaches like the Theory of Planned Behavior highlighting the interconnections among normative and behavioral beliefs. At least in the context of voting beliefs, normative and behavioral beliefs tended to cluster together rather than being segregated into separate clusters as might be predicted by theory. Similarly, self-related and social beliefs also tended to cluster together, mirroring previous findings that self-related and social motives are tightly linked in the context of message perception and sharing (Cosme et al., 2023;Cosme et al., 2025;Falk & Scholz, 2017). Third, these findings add further evidence that communication interventions that increase the salience of self-related and social motives can encourage prosocial behavior, such as voting, and information sharing (Albarracín et al., 2024;Cosme et al., 2025;Costa et al., 2018;French Bourgeois & de la Sablonnière, 2023;Sinclair et al., 2025). Importantly, our results suggest that at least in the context of youth voting, it may be more effective to target self-related beliefs, which can in turn activate social beliefs, as opposed to targeting social beliefs since the messages targeting social beliefs tended to be less effective. Finally, our results underscore how social norms and values like a sense of civic duty can be internalized so that they become core personal values (Bali et al., 2020;Lydic et al., 2025). Appeals to civic duty (Gerber & Green, 2017) and normative social pressure (Gerber et al., 2008;Panagopoulos, 2010;Rogers et al., 2017) are common in GOTV campaigns, but have the potential to backfire if they are perceived as controlling. Our findings suggest that communication interventions that help individuals identify why voting is aligned with their core values is another pathway to activate a sense of civic duty.

div.head: Practical implications
div.p: Beyond theoretical advancements, this project also has clear implications for practitioners seeking to develop youth-focused GOTV messaging. This research demonstrates that it is possible to develop persuasive and motivating GOTV messages that are nonpartisan by targeting promising beliefs in open-ended ways that allow the audience to reflect on the issues most relevant to themselves and their communities. It also indicates that communication interventions should go beyond simply providing informational content to overcome psychological barriers to voting. These results suggest that targeting behavioral beliefs about the personal relevance and importance of voting, the significance of an individual vote, and the impact the election will have on personally-relevant issues and outcomes may be impactful. Overall, we found that beliefs about the self-relevance and importance of voting and the personal consequences of the election tended to be the most promising and influential. Therefore, GOTV messaging campaigns and communication interventions that help individuals connect the act of voting to their core values and concerns may have greater potential to strengthen voting intentions.

This project also highlights the synergistic potential of adopting an iterative, participatory research approach to conduct formative research and co-design messages in partnership with youth. From a practical standpoint, scaling nonpartisan GOTV efforts requires strategically targeting beliefs about voting, particularly pertaining to the self-relevance of voting and voter efficacy, while ensuring clarity, minimal partisan cues, strong visuals, and authenticity through community-based design. We demonstrate that this approach can yield better political communication interventions while simultaneously serving as an opportunity to strengthen youth research skills and support civic education, development, and empowerment (Ozer et al., 2024). As was the case in our team, this framework can also create opportunities for noncitizen students to promote nonpartisan civic engagement. In sum, engaging in participatory action research in partnership with youth can lead to more effective political communication interventions and also create a positive culture of civic efficacy and collaboration between youth and adult researchers.

div.head: Limitations and future directions
div.p: These promising findings should be interpreted in light of several limitations. First, we cannot disentangle the two key features of our design process-formative research and message development-to determine the impact of each process in isolation. Rather, we show that co-design in the process of formative research and message development led to substantially better message effectiveness. Second, we focused on message-related perceptions and voting intentions rather than voting-related behavior (e.g., registration and voting). Although we did not directly measure voting behavior, the robust effects observed here suggest that theory-informed, co-designed communication interventions hold promise in closing the gap between concern about politics, intentions to vote, and actual voting behavior. In line with this, a recent field experiment showed that messages communicating the personal impact of voting increased voter turnout in a local election (Huber et al., 2022). Future research could investigate whether these immediate message-related effects translate into meaningful, lasting changes in voter registration or turnout. Third, we used controlled experimental methods to investigate message effectiveness and therefore cannot draw inferences about how effective these messages would be in situ. Research using field study methods to evaluate message effectiveness on real social media platforms is an important future direction, especially since prior research on GOTV campaigns targeting youth on social media have yielded mixed results (Unan et al., 2024;Teresi & Michelson, 2015). Fourth, we applied the belief network approach post-hoc and therefore future studies should examine its ability to guide identification of promising beliefs and message development from the outset. Fifth, although our samples were adequately powered for all analyses presented here, they precluded deeper exploration of demographic and individual differences in voting beliefs and message effects; future studies designed for this purpose would provide important contextual information to inform youth-focused GOTV campaigns. Finally, we collaborated with college students to design GOTV messages to motivate their peers to vote but did not test the degree to which voting beliefs and messages generalize to youth not enrolled in college. This is an important future direction as this group is contacted frequently by GOTV campaigns (CIRCLE, 2022) and therefore may especially benefit from receiving and shaping the development of GOTV communication interventions.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In a political climate where young adults are often characterized as disengaged, this study demonstrates the potential for theory-based, co-created messaging to bolster motivation to vote in this group. By integrating formative research with participatory co-design, we developed messages that outperformed national youth-focused communication campaigns in their immediate psychological impact. These promising findings testify to the reciprocal benefits of combining theoretical rigor with the lived insights of the communities that campaigns aim to engage. In doing so, they offer a blueprint for communication scholars, practitioners, and civic organizations seeking to catalyze meaningful engagement among emerging generations of voters. Crucially, research partnerships between these groups creates a framework that enables rapid translation of research into direct implementation, which in turn can inform the next cycle of research through insights gained from implementation. As civic and educational organizations look to scale their efforts, embedding co-design throughout the research and delivery pipeline offers a clear path toward messages that are at once persuasive, portable, and powerfully rooted in community experience.

div.head: Correlations between belief centrality and percentage to gain
div.p: The correlation between belief centrality and percentage to gain reported in the main manuscript is visualized in Figure S1. Correlations with intentions to register and make a plan, and voting attitudes, subjective norms, and perceived behavioral control Identification of promising beliefs to target in messaging used intentions to vote as the primary outcome of interest. Here we report correlations between each belief and participants' intentions to register to vote among those not already registered ( N = 76), and intentions to make a plan to vote, and voting attitudes, subjective norms, and perceived behavioral control in all participants ( N = 274).

div.head: Associations between promising belief metrics and message effectiveness
div.p: We conducted post-hoc analyses examining relationships between percentage to gain and belief centrality for the beliefs targeted in each message and message effectiveness. The primary and secondary beliefs targeted by each message are listed for each message on OSF: https://osf.io/axrc7 . We combined data from the Message development and testing samples and averaged centrality and percentage to gain across all beliefs targeted in each message to get a single value for each, per message. We then fit linear mixed effects models regressing each measure of message effectiveness (composite effectiveness score, argument strength, and belief strength) on all potential models including the fixed effects of centrality and percentage to gain (i.e., main effects of each separately, main effects of both, and the interaction between them), as well as intercept only models. In each model, intercepts were Study 3: Message experiment Descriptives for all message-level variables

In addition to the primary outcomes reported in the main manuscript, participants rated several secondary outcome measures using the same sliding scale (0 = strongly disagree, 100 = strongly agree): social relevance ("This message is relevant to people I know"), willingness to broadcast ("I would share this message by posting on social media"), willingness to narrowcast ("I would share this message directly with someone I know"), positive emotions ("This message makes me feel hopeful, optimistic, or inspired"), negative emotions ("This message makes me feel fearful, anxious, or worried"), message nonpartisanship ("This message is nonpartisan"), and aesthetics ("This message is visually appealing"). Descriptive statistics for each message type are reported in Table S9 and correlations among variables are reported in Table S10.

div.head: Generalizability analyses
div.p: We examined how well the messages generalized to a National student sample compared to the Local student sample at our institution where formative research was conducted. Across message types, we found that there were no statistically significant differences between the Local and National student samples (Table 7; Figure 4B). The National sample rated the control messages as slightly more motivating ( b = 5.58, p = .067), but the difference between co-designed and control messages were similar in magnitude ( b s = -0.82 --1.68, p s > .05). That is, there were no statistically significant interactions between message source and sample, indicating that the co-designed messages were similarly effective for college students locally and nationally.

div.head: List of beliefs
div.p: The full list of beliefs used in Study 1 are listed in Table S1.

div.head: Results
div.p: The number of people who either strongly hold a belief ("yes") or don't ("no") and the percent to move (i.e., the percent of people who do not strongly hold a belief) is listed in Table S2. Mean belief strength as a function of group (intenders and non-intenders), mean differences between groups, correlation between belief strength and voting intentions, percentage of people with strong voting intentions in each group, and the percentage to gain for all beliefs are listed in Table S3.

div.head: Message development sample ratings
div.p: Ratings for each message are reported in Table S6.

allowed to vary randomly across participants and messages. We used the Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) to compare models and treated a decrease in AIC of at least 2 points to be considered a better fitting model. When two models had less than a 2-point difference, we interpret the more expansive model. Model comparisons are reported in Table S7 and results from the best fitting models are reported in Table S8. For illustrative purposes, model fitted predictions from the models that include the main effects of both percentage to gain and belief centrality are visualized in Figure S2.

The best fitting models either only included belief centrality or the main effects of both centrality and percentage to gain. In all models, belief centrality was the strongest predictor of message effectiveness. The best fitting model for argument strength did not include percentage to gain and this measure was not associated with argument strength (Figure S2).

div.head: Secondary analyses: Message sharing and affective responses to messages
div.p: In preregistered secondary analyses, we investigated the effect of message source (co-designed vs. control) on message sharing and affect. Models were fit using the same approach described in the main manuscript. We expected that participants would have higher intentions to broadcast-share widely such as on social media-and narrowcast-share with specific individuals-the co-designed messages compared to the control messages. In line with this hypothesis, we found that the co-designed messages elicited slightly stronger broad-and narrowcast sharing intentions than control messages (Table S11). With respect to affective ratings, we expected that the co-designed messages would evoke more positive emotion than the control messages. We did not preregister a hypothesis about negative emotion, but include this as an exploratory outcome. We found that co-designed messages evoked both more positive and negative emotions than control messages (Table S11). Sensitivity analyses: Controlling for aesthetic quality and nonpartisanship

We conducted sensitivity analyses including aesthetic quality and nonpartisan ratings in the primary models reported in the main manuscript. Controlling for these variables reduced the magnitude of the message source effects, but all remain statistically significant (Table S12). This exploratory analysis aimed to identify which messages were most effective overall. We fit a linear mixed effects model regressing each outcome separately on the fixed effect of message; intercepts were allowed to vary randomly across participants. Figure S3 shows the marginal effects for each message. All co-designed messages were rated as motivating, persuasive, and self-relevant (i.e., means are >50, the scale midpoint), whereas control messages tended to be rated as not motivating and not persuasive. Overall, the co-designed messages tended to be the most motivating and persuasive, but results were more mixed for self-relevance. The most motivating and persuasive message targeted the belief that an individual's vote doesn't matter.

div.head: Preregistered secondary analyses: Student control messages
div.p: In the Local sample, we also tested a set of secondary control messages that were obtained from an internal repository of prior social media posts from Penn Leads the Vote, a student-led GOTV organization at our institution. The purpose of including these messages was to compare the effectiveness of our messages that were co-designed with youth and targeted promising beliefs, relative to messages that were designed by youth but without evidence-based belief targeting. These secondary control messages were evaluated for inclusion based on the same criteria as our primary control messages from Rock the Vote. This resulted in 10 secondary control messages, including 5 generic messages, 3 informational messages, and 2 persuasive messages. In addition to the co-designed and Rock the Vote control messages, participants in the Local sample saw an additional random sample of 5 out of 10 secondary control messages.

We expected that the student control messages would be more self-relevant since they are tailored to the Local sample, and thus predicted that the co-designed messages would be more motivating and persuasive than the student control message and at least as self-relevant. In line with these preregistered hypotheses, we found that compared to the student control messages across message types, the co-designed messages were more motivating and persuasive, and were similarly self-relevant (Table S13; Figure S4). As expected, we also found that the co-designed messages were more motivating and persuasive than all message types. However, in contrast to our predictions, the co-designed messages were rated as less self-relevant than persuasive and informational messages, and similarly self-relevant as generic messages. We also conducted analyses examining our secondary outcomes of interest. As in the primary analyses, the co-designed messages evoked more negative emotion than the control messages (Table S14). In contrast to the primary analyses, participants reported lower narrowcast sharing intentions for the co-designed compared to the student control messages. Co-designed and student control messages elicited similar broadcast sharing intentions and positive emotions.
